thread.title_full: Hayley Scanlan accuses New Look of stealing her designs | Daily Mail Online

author: James Dunn For Mailonline
title: Hayley Scanlan accuses New Look of stealing her designs
text:
A fashion designer whose clothes have been work by Little Mix, The Saturdays and Jessie J has accused New Look of 'plagiarism on the high street' after it 'copied' on of her designs.
Hayley Scanlan, whose clothes have featured in Vogue, claims that the chain has released a T-shirt for Â£11.99 that is identical to one of her designs and now on sale in stores nationwide.
The top, from the store's teenage range, features the same 'Midnight Blue' slogan in a similar lettering and includes the phrase 'Stay True' - the name of her last collection.
Fashion designer Hayley Scanlan (pictured) has accused New Look of 'plagiarism on the high street' after claiming they stole a design
The 32-year-old designer from Dundee, twice named Young Scottish Designer of the Year, slammed the national clothing chain in an angry social media post.
She said: 'Not only have you completely copied the name of my last collection (and also noticeably the 'Stay True' part my sister & I came up with) but you've used pretty much the exact same font for a T-shirt currently selling in your stores and online, blatantly making money from my work. I am actually gobsmacked.
'Waiting patiently on a reply, especially when you have stolen my design work.'
She says it is not the first time someone had ripped off one of her creations. In October she posted after spotting a dress almost identical to one of her most popular designs.
In an emotional message posted at the time, she said: 'The reason of this post is because this happens to us time after time and also many other designers, most recently it's came to light in the press that other major high street brands have decided to rip off other designers work and it is just not acceptable. Plagiarism is a crime.
'My point is - would a fellow songwriter copy the lyrics of another songwriters song but change the title? Would and author copy the words of a fellow authors book but change the cover? Would an artist copy a fellow artists painting but change the size of the painting? Think about it.
The top, from New Look's teenage range, features the same 'Midnight Blue' slogan in a similar lettering to Miss Scanlan's and includes the phrase 'Stay True' - the name of her last collection
Miss Scanlan (pictured), twice named Scottish Designer of the Year, slammed the high street store publicly on social media and has demanded a response
'My point is - would a fellow songwriter copy the lyrics of another songwriters song but change the title? Would and author copy the words of a fellow authors book but change the cover? Would an artist copy a fellow artists painting but change the size of the painting? Think about it.
'This post just isn't about us but for all the other independent designers out there who have experienced this, it's time to raise awareness to plagiarism in Fashion and put a stop to this, hopefully it does and we can all move on, do what we love, respect each other's work and be happy.'
Bloggers and fans have since branded the alleged plagiarism 'outrageous'.
New Look has confirmed it will be investigating the allegations, promising that the complaints will be 'looked into thoroughly'.
Fellow design graduate Emily Huggins said: 'Of all the plagiarism I've seen by high street brands, this is by far the most outrageous.
Miss Scanlan is due to open her maiden Dundee store soon.
The Perth Road premises will sell clothes from the designer's diffusion line H.S as well as provide a showroom for her latest designs.
Miss Scanlan, 32, attended Dundee University's Duncan of Jordanstone before catching the eye of supermodel Erin O'Connor, who commissioned a leather jacket from the designer.
